metadata.sermon_start_end: You may have noticed that ever since 9/11 President Bush has been saying emphatically that events would unfold “at a time of our choosing.” This is the way that powerful people tend to speak. It is also the way that nonpowerful people sometimes speak in order to gain a taste [...] The One who has sent his Son to rescue the “children of wrath” is God. And the ultimate outcome, for all of us warring human beings, belongs to God. Thanks be to God. “We are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand, that we should walk in them.” Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on Ephesians 2, specifically the transition from 'dead in sin' to 'alive in Christ.' However, it leans heavily on the 'three-party' concept which, while present, is interpreted through the lens of Tolkien and contemporary war reporting rather than extracting the unique 'nowhere else' quality of this specific text. It risks becoming a thematic speech on 'the Enemy' rather than a strict recreation of the pericope.
quotes: To see this, we look at our reading from Ephesians for today.
The story told in Ephesians... is that there are three active agencies, not two—and the three are (1) God, (2) all (not just some) of humanity, and (3) the Enemy.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what Ephesians 2:1-10 says about the 'prince of the power of the air' that distinguishes it from other Pauline descriptions of evil, and focus more on the 'sitting in heavenly places' aspect which is unique to this text.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no formal exposition of the original context, the city of Ephesus, or the specific theological vocabulary of the Greek text. The preacher replaces historical-critical exegesis with literary and political analogies (Tolkien, Iraq War). The 'religious history' required by Dekker is absent.
quotes: The figure of Satan is symbolic; this symbolism functions to show us that the Enemy of God is a personal intelligence...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the actual historical context of the Ephesian audience—their background in magic and 'powers'—to ground the 'prince of the power of the air' in its original setting before moving to modern analogies.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. The application to the Iraq War, the psychology of soldiers, and the critique of American 'innocence' is highly concrete and avoids generalities. It demonstrates the 'broad knowledge of humanities' and 'zeitgeist' Dekker demands.
quotes: At the base camp of the Fifth Marine regiment in Iraq, two sharpshooters traded war stories...
Push us just a little bit more and a little bit more and we too are capable of mistreating prisoners and killing children...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application remains anchored in the text's specific promise of 'good works prepared beforehand' rather than just psychological observation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the 'block' structure. It moves back and forth between the text of Ephesians and the realities of the war. The hearer is 'expounded' alongside the text.
quotes: Let’s listen to these two stories with our three-part drama in mind.
But then the apostle continues, laying out before us the true state of things in the world.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Deepen the theological 'why' behind the application so the movement from text to world feels less like an illustration and more like a necessary revelation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The three parts are clearly present. Misery is defined as being 'dead' and under the 'Enemy.' Redemption is the 'But God' intervention. Gratitude is the 'good works' at the end. The sermon correctly identifies man as the subject of this movement.
quotes: Until God intervened with his gift of life, he writes, you were dead.
God has already prepared our good choices for us... that we should walk in them.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'gratitude' section is slightly rushed at the end; it needs more weight to balance the extensive 'misery' section.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the seriousness of 'being lost' in time (the corruption of the soul in war). However, it leans toward a universalist conclusion ('ultimate outcome, for all of us... belongs to God') which may soften the 'two ways' Dekker insists upon.
quotes: The end of that story is that we all end up as 'children of wrath.'
The ultimate outcome, for all of us warring human beings, belongs to God.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Clarify the reality of the 'broad way' that leads to destruction, ensuring the 'choice' of the hearer is taken as seriously as the 'vote' of the Enemy.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: While Christ is mentioned as the one who makes us alive, He functions more as a mechanism of God's victory than the personal 'telos' or the 'two natures' figure Dekker describes. The sermon is more Theo-centric than Christo-centric.
quotes: made us alive together with Christ (by grace you have been saved)
The One who holds the future of the human race is God, and God alone.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly address the person of Christ as the one in whom the 'two natures' meet, making the 'sitting in heavenly places' a concrete reality for the believer.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16 minutes (1650 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum requirement. It lacks the 'breadth' needed for the 'depth' of this cosmic text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the required length and provide a firmer foundation for the contemporary application.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a sharp, contemporary address that excels in psychological and cultural application but falls short in formal exegesis and duration. It correctly identifies the 'misery' of the human condition and the necessity of external grace, yet it risks substituting literary archetypes (Tolkien) for rigorous biblical exposition. The Christology remains somewhat functional rather than central.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of specific war reports avoids the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
Psychological depth: It effectively reclaims the 'misery' of the human soul from secular psychology.
Interwoven structure: The text and the contemporary situation are analyzed in a single movement.
weaknesses: Lack of original context: No evidence of Hebrew/Greek knowledge or historical-critical depth.
Insufficient length: At 16 minutes, it lacks the 'breadth' required by Dekker/Miskotte.
Vague Christology: Christ is the means of salvation but not clearly the 'telos' of the sermon's movement.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate piece of proclamatory speaking, but it is a 'weak' sermon by Dekker's standards due to the lack of scholarly exposition and insufficient length. It functions more as a theological commentary on current events than a recreation of the Word of God from the specific Greek text of Ephesians.
